title: Thrifty money blogger reveals how you can start food planning in 2017… and save a bundle on your shopping
text:
Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments OUR supermarket food shop can take a big chunk out of our monthly budgets, so with a little tweaking – savvy shoppers can save hundreds of pounds on their food bill. 
Food and money blogger Michelle Rice from Utterly Scrummy Food For Families gave the Sun Online her savvy tips to help beginners get a handle on meal planning. Marelle Rice 4 Michelle Rice is a money and food blogger who has given us her top tips on food planning for 2017 
She said: “One of the best ways to save money on your grocery costs is to plan your meals. 
“Meal planning can seem overwhelming if you’ve never done it before, and even more so if you have to stick to a tight budget. 
“To get the most value for money, you will need to plan meals around what’s already in your pantry, and what’s on special offer and/or in season.” Do a stock-take and use what you have 
The best way to save money on food, is to make sure you actually use everything in your cupboard before going out to buy new products. Alamy 4 According to money blogger Michelle, the easiest way to save money on food is to use what you have first 
Michelle advised: “See how many meals you can make using the food you already have. You’ll probably be surprised at how many meals you can whip up using the ingredients lurking in your cupboards, freezer and fridge.” Use less meat 
Meat doesn’t come cheap, so the more meals you can leave it out of, the cheaper your food bill will be. “If you can plan a few meals a week that are meat-free then you are sure to save money. 
“Try planning meals around cheap proteins like beans/pulses or eggs. Frozen fish can also be a cost effective option. 
“Also, you can bulk out meals with vegetables to make less meat go further.” RELATED STORIES UK’S MOST FRUGAL MUM Thrifty mum to only buy her two kids second hand goods for a whole year in protest over Christmas waste Weight off your mind Thrifty mum reveals how she's HALVED her Christmas food bill - with the help of some body builders Quids in Thrifty food blogger reveals how YOU can cook Christmas dinner for less than £1 per person Santa's Little Saver Thrifty mum of two reveals how she got £1,300 worth of Christmas presents for £500 the wheel deal Thrifty drivers can buy a car AND run it for three years for just over £7,000 Cook from scratch when you can 
If you want to save some money on food, it is all about cooking from scratch whenever you can. Michelle told us: “Convenience food has its place, but shouldn’t be relied upon all the time, especially when you’re on a tight budget. 
“Anything that you can learn to make at home instead of buying it will save you money. 
“A homemade pasta sauce can be made for pennies, and will contain much more flavour and much less sugar than some commercially made ones.” Make the most of expensive ingredients 
If you want to cut down on your food costs, there’s no need to only eat lentils and carrots. Michelle says you can still eat luxurious items. Getty Images 4 You don’t have to just eat cheaper proteins such as beans – just make sure your expensive ones go far 
The blogger explained: “If we have a roast chicken for dinner one night, I make another two meals with the leftover chicken and stock with the carcass. 
“Use good quality sausages, with a high percentage of meat, to flavour a stew that will last a couple of nights, or dinner and a couple of lunches.” Love your leftovers 
If you’re throwing out food, you’re as good as throwing out cash – and leftovers don’t have to be tedious . Michelle said: “We don’t waste anything if we can possibly avoid it. 
“I quite often make double the amount of dinner so we can enjoy a quick dinner later in the week. Getty Images 4 Michelle believes that if you are wasting food, then you are wasting money 
“If we have small portions of leftover dinner, I freeze the in smaller portions for a quick toddler dunner, or in larger portions for teenagers to defrost, reheat and eat, before they dash off to evening clubs.” Thrifty food blogger reveals how YOU can cook Christmas dinner for less than £1
